June 2020 
 
 
 
 
Republic of Uzbekistan: Road Subsector 
Development Strategy and Action Plan

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will provide advisory support to 
guide road subsector governance reforms in Uzbekistan, which will help strengthen relevant 
institutions, improve the country’s road network, and make infrastructure assets more sustainable. 
The TA is not included in the country operations business plan for Uzbekistan, 2020–2022.1 The 
government requested assistance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for the TA on 17 
February 2020.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Inadequate trade competitiveness.  Uzbekistan located in the heart of Central Asia, is 
doubly landlocked (as it is surrounded by similarly landlocked countries) and suffers as well from 
deteriorating road infrastructure and cumbersome logistics processes. In 2018, the country 
ranked 99th out of 160 ranked countries in terms of its logistics performance. The low ranking 
(120th) for timeliness of international shipments is attributable mainly to Uzbekistan’s landlocked 
location, as well as inadequate logistics facilities and processes. The ranking for quality of 
infrastructure remains low (77th) in 2018, although an improvement from 99th in 2016.3 
 
3.  Capacity expansion and financing. Strong economic growth and a concomitant surge 
in traffic have led to the need to improve and expand the road network. To do this as efficiently 
and effectively as possible, Uzbekistan needs a prioritized road investment program that has a 
realistic  financing  plan  and  addresses  the  management  of  climate  risk.  Funding  from  the 
government and development partners is unlikely to meet financing needs, and the government 
will need to explore the potential for public–private partnerships and similar road construction and 
maintenance arrangements. Road projects meeting public–private partnership standards will be 
identified through the overall road investment and financing strategy and action plan. 
 
4.  Need for road subsector reform. In 2019, the World Bank prepared a transport sector 
policy strategy paper aimed to underpin the Transport and Logistics Strategy of the Government 
of Uzbekistan.4 The policy paper defined the components of a comprehensive strategy and 
identified areas needing further analysis and refinement. The TA will complement the World Bank 
policy paper by detailing areas in the road subsector for which the World Bank has provided only 
general recommendations. This division of roles and tasks was discussed at a high-level transport 
sector coordination meeting held in Tashkent in January 2020 and endorsed by the government. 
 
5.  Institutional reforms. Significant road sector governance reforms have been enacted 
since 2006, but further reforms are needed. The Ministry of Transport (created in 2019) is 
responsible for transport sector planning, policy formulation, regulation, and oversight. The 
Committee for Roads is the key road agency and responsible for the operation and maintenance 
of the network of common use roads. The Committee for Road’s organizational structure may be 
compared with a holding company, which does not deliver services itself, but exercises its 
responsibilities through subsidiaries, of which it is the sole shareholder. The subsidiaries include 
government departments as well as state-owned enterprises (SOEs) with various legal forms. 
 
1  The government request for the project emerged after COBP, 2020–2022. In country programming mission in April 
2020, the government reiterated its request, which is reflected in the Cabinet of Ministers’ resolution. The project is 
included in the current year’s non-lending products list in draft COBP, 2021–2023. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 23 April 2020. 
3  World Bank. 2018. The Logistics Performance Index and its Indicators. Washington, DC. 
4  World Bank. 2019. Uzbekistan - Building Blocks for Integrated Transport and Logistics Development. Draft November 
2019.

2 
Steps have been taken to commercialize the SOEs, but many remain closely linked to the 
Committee for Roads and the government. In order to improve sector governance and enhance 
efficiency and competition, the government is determined to privatize the SOEs. 
 
6.  Need for modern design standards. Uzbekistan’s road design standards originate from 
standards that prevailed in the former Soviet Union; they do not adequately reflect economic 
considerations, such as traffic volumes and loads, or adequately address emerging issues such 
as road safety, and climate change mitigation and adaptation. The former Soviet Union standards 
are conducive to the overdesign of roads, and the ensuing robust designs are largely what have 
enabled Uzbekistan’s roads to endure for many years despite inadequate maintenance practices. 
The more densely trafficked international and national roads in Uzbekistan suffer from a backlog 
in periodic maintenance and rehabilitation. The share of roads in poor condition is rising, and 
many are highly trafficked roads, making it urgent that robust pavement designs are introduced, 
coupled with an improved maintenance regime. 
 
7.  Sustainability of the road assets. Government expenditures on roads are financed from 
several sources, none of which are directly earmarked for roads. None of the government taxes 
applied to road operation and maintenance act as a price that would reflect the impacts and costs 
associated with road users’ utilization of road pavements. Road infrastructure is among the 
government’s most valuable assets, but does not receive adequate maintenance financing; this 
stems in part from the limited budget allocated to road maintenance, and because of changes in 
the Republican Road Fund resulting from a new (2019) presidential decree.5 Maintenance 
backlogs are mounting, and in response, the government is considering introducing a road asset 
management system. The TA will familiarize the Committee for Roads with the concept of road 
asset management and the requirements to introduce the system; the actual introduction of a 
road asset management system would exceed the financial and time resources of the TA. 
 
8.  Road safety. There are an estimated 550 road fatalities in Uzbekistan per year, and the 
associated costs equal about 1% of gross domestic product per year. Prerequisites for sustained 
road safety improvements include a gender-inclusive information system for traffic monitoring, 
adequate engineering standards, enforcement of traffic rules, and improved driver behavior. 
 
9.  Alignment with ADB’s Strategy 2030. Consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2030, the TA will 
help ensure sustainable infrastructure investments in a manner that also addresses climate 
change issues.6 The approach to developing road designs will take into consideration potential 
impacts from climate change, and will thereby improve road network resilience. The TA is also 
aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy for Uzbekistan, 2019–2023, which recognizes 
public  governance,  old  and  deteriorated  infrastructure,  and  constraints  to  private  sector 
development as key challenges.7 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) long-term prosperity driven by increased 
trade competitiveness resulting from the development of viable and environmentally and socially 
 
5  Decree of the President of Republic of Uzbekistan No. UP-5890 dated 9 December 2019. Measures for Reforms of 
the Road System of the Republic of Uzbekistan. Tashkent. 
6  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
7  ADB. 2019. Country Partnership Strategy: Uzbekistan, 2019–2023—Supporting Economic Transformation. Manila.

3 
sustainable transport infrastructure and services realized (footnote 6), and (ii) public health 
promoted through safer roads and traffic conditions.8 The TA will have the following outcome: 
road subsector governance improved.9 
 
B.  Output, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  The TA will support the design of priority reforms in the road subsector, and guide the 
government in the initial implementation phases. TA activities have been designed according to 
four criteria: (i) alignment with government priorities, (ii) harmonization with the support provided 
by  other  partners,  (iii)  likely  feasibility  of  interventions,  and  (iv)  synergies  with  other  ADB 
operations.  
 
12.  Output: Road subsector development strategy and action plan developed. The TA 
will produce a road subsector development strategy and an accompanying time-bound gender- 
and socially inclusive action plan to clearly lay out the priority reforms needed in the road 
subsector and guide the government in their implementation. The strategy will outline enhanced 
institutional arrangements in the road subsector, including the roles and responsibilities of existing 
government institutions as well as the private sector. It will also generate options for further 
development  of  subsector  institutions.  The  TA  will  identify  appropriate  road  maintenance 
strategies  for the  Committee  for  Roads  and  identify modern  road cross  section  with  road 
infrastructure. It will also include a methodology for prioritizing investments in the road subsector, 
and articulate additional financing options for private sector investments. The action plan will be 
monitored  closely  by  the  government  using  a  monitoring  framework  containing  key  sex-
disaggregated performance indicators. 
 
13.  The TA will build on the work completed through ADB’s previous and ongoing support10 
to the Uzbekistan road sector.11 Evaluation of previous TA support for governance reforms has 
highlighted that successful reform requires time and flexibility.12 The TA will propose innovative 
planning, design and state-of-the-art construction techniques in road infrastructure, and propose 
changes in existing codes, standards and specification being used  by the Committee for Roads. 
This is reflected in the indicative TA implementation period. Moreover, an interactive approach 
throughout implementation will ensure government ownership of the results. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered by ADB.13 The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The government will provide counterpart support in 
 
8  ADB. 2017. Safely Connected: A Regional Road Safety Strategy for CAREC Countries, 2017–2030. Manila. 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
10 ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Uzbekistan for Transport Sector Strategy (2006–2020). Manila 
(TA 4659-UZB, approved on 3 October, financed by the Japan Sector Fund); ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance to 
the Republic of Uzbekistan for Eligibility of State-owned Road Enterprises for Participation in ADB-financed Projects. 
Manila (TA 7053-UZB, approved on 24 January); and ADB. 1998. Report and Recommendation of the President to 
the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Technical Grant to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Road Rehabilitation 
Project. Manila. 
11 Presidential Decree of the Republic of Uzbekistan No. 4545. 2019. On Measures to Further Improve the Road 
Management System. Tashkent.  
12 ADB. 2014. Supporting Good Governance: A Thematic Evaluation Study of ADB Support for Enhancing Governance 
in its Public Sector Operations - Governance in Transport and Energy Projects. Manila. 
13 On 31 March 2020, the e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund application was approved by the Government of 
the Republic of Korea.

4 
the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, logistics and administrative support, and 
other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA and will have full responsibility for disbursement of TA funds. 
The Transport and Communications Division of ADB’s Central and West Asia Department will 
select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; organize workshops; and provide quality assurance 
and coordination of all TA inputs. The Committee for Roads will act as the executing agency, with 
the Republican Road Fund as the implementing agency. The Ministry of Investments and Foreign 
Trade  will  chair  a  steering  committee  comprising  senior  representatives  from  relevant  line 
ministries, the implementing agency, and transport system users. The main tasks of the steering 
committee will be to (i) oversee the development of a shared vision and clear policy objectives, 
(ii) provide overall guidance to the consultant team, (iii) make key decisions, and (iv) approve the 
action plan once completed. 
 
16.  ADB will coordinate all TA activities closely with the Government of Uzbekistan, notably 
with  the  Committee  for  Roads  and  the  Ministry  of  Investments  and  Foreign  Trade.  The 
development partners—including the World Bank, the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, and 
the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development—will be briefed from time to time on TA 
implementation progress.  
 
17.  The consultant team will closely work with the Committee for Roads and the steering 
committee to carry out the tasks assigned to them. Each international expert will be matched with 
a national expert; a total of 12-person months of international expert services and 14-person 
months of national expert services will be recruited to implement the TA. 
 
18.  The consultants will be selected and engaged as individual consultants. This selection 
modality will address the government’s need for an expeditious and custom-tailored delivery of 
the TA outputs. The Committee for Roads, based on the understandings reached with ADB and 
other development partners, had made a commitment to the Ministry of Transport to submit the 
consultants’ recommendations by October 2020. 
 
19.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

21.  Cofinancier  requirements.  The  TA  will  be  monitored  as  guided  by  the  standard 
requirements of the e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
to the Government of Uzbekistan to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia 
and Knowledge Partnership Fund for the Road Subsector Development Strategy and Action Plan, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
15 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
